channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Abducted Nigerian Girls Have Not Been Abandoned, U.S. Says
item.media:description: Cameroonian soldiers in Kolofata, Cameroon, last month. Besides Nigeria, Cameroon has been the country hardest hit by the militant group Boko Haram, which now operates out of bases in the Mandara Mountains, Sambisa Forest and the Lake Chad area.
item.description: American forces have helped locate small groups of the 276 girls abducted by Boko Haram two years ago this month, but officials say a rescue is risky.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Patricio Aylwin, President Who Guided Chile to Democracy, Dies at 97
item.media:description: Patricio Aylwin, right, with Gen. Augusto Pinochet in Santiago, Chile, in 1993.
item.description: Mr. Aylwin, the first civilian elected after the Pinochet dictatorship, created a truth commission to investigate human rights abuses.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: In Remote Ecuador Towns Hit by Quake, Contact Was Cut Off for Days
item.description: New York Times journalists accompanied an aid mission to a devastated area without water, power or the means to contact the outside world.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and MAGGY AYALA

item.title: Brazil Impeachment Debate Hinges on a Thorny Legal Question
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil at a news conference on Tuesday called a move to impeach her a “legal and political fraud.”
item.description: There is broad agreement that President Dilma Rousseff’s administration employed budgetary tricks, but legal experts are divided on whether that amounts to an impeachable offense.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Senator Says He May Back Bill Exposing Saudis to 9/11 Lawsuits
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, left, the majority leader, and Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, leave a Senate policy luncheon on Tuesday. Mr. McConnell has declined to give his full support to the Sept. 11 bill, saying he would need to study the measure more carefully.
item.description: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said he would drop his opposition to the bill if its sponsors agreed to changes seeking to protect American interests abroad.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.title: Mother Facing Kidnapping Charges in Australian Custody Dispute Is Released
item.media:description: Sally Faulkner, front, and Tara Brown were among those released from prison in Lebanon on Wednesday.
item.description: Sally Faulkner and a four-person television crew were charged with kidnapping at gunpoint and threatening the lives of children.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Norway Violated Rights of Anders Behring Breivik, Mass Killer, Judge Rules
item.media:description: Anders Behring Breivik on March 18, the last day of a court hearing about the conditions of his confinement in a prison in Skien, Norway.
item.description: Mr. Breivik had argued that the conditions of his confinement, including restrictions on communication, were a violation of the European Convention of Human Rights.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II, No Stranger to Full Agenda, Pencils In a 90th Birthday
item.description: Befitting a workhorse who carried out 341 engagements last year, Elizabeth kicked off celebrations on Wednesday in a dutiful display.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Beijing Journal: Chinese Feminism’s Long March Takes Two Paths at Bookstores
item.media:description: The founder of Lady Book Salon, Xu Chunyu, in Beijing this month. Since opening two years ago, Lady Book Salon has become a refuge for working women seeking spiritual fulfillment and a place to trade advice on managing families and careers.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The Lady Book Salon offers philosophy and career guidance, as well as cookbooks and advice on finding a husband.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Timing of Editor’s Firing Has Hong Kong Worried About Press Freedom
item.media:description: The front page of the Ming Pao newspaper on Wednesday.
item.description: Keung Kwok-yuen, the No. 2 editor at Ming Pao, was fired after the publication of a story on the Panama Papers and the offshore holdings of Hong Kong tycoons.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: France Seeks to Extend Emergency Powers as It Prepares for Sports Events
item.media:description: Special operations officers during a training exercise at a rail station in Paris on Wednesday.
item.description: The government is aiming to bolster security before the country hosts the European Championship soccer tournament and the Tour de France this summer.
item.dc:creator: BENOIT MORENNE

item.title: India to Seek Return of Koh-i-Noor Diamond From Britain
item.media:description: The Koh-i-noor diamond is on a crown, crafted in 1937, that was most recently used by the Queen Mother, who died in 2002 at age 101.
item.description: The 105.6-carat stone, which is part of the crown jewels and is on view at the Tower of London, has been in the country since 1850.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere: China Drone Users, Beware: Maker Says It May Share Data With State
item.media:description: A Phantom 3 drone by DJI, which has helped to popularize drones.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: The company, DJI, said that it was still working out how to deal with the data the authorities request and that it could include data from flights in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Death Toll in Kabul Explosion Rises to 64, Afghan Official Says
item.media:description: A funeral on Wednesday for a victim killed in a vehicle bombing the day before in Kabul, the Afghan capital.
item.description: Speaking a day after the Taliban attack in the Afghan capital, the Interior Ministry spokesman said that the number of wounded had also increased, to 347.
item.dc:creator: JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Obama Arrives in Saudi Arabia Amid a New Round of Contention
item.media:description: President Obama with King Salman at Erga Palace in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Wednesday.
item.description: The president visited Riyadh just a day after backing the release of documents said to implicate Saudi officials in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Sinosphere: Jianbing, a Chinese Crepe, Migrates to Manhattan
item.media:description: The Flying Pig Jianbing’s food truck in Manhattan is a converted French crepe maker that now turns out jianbing, the savory Chinese pancakes.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: A street-food crepe from northern China, jianbing, is Beijing’s latest culinary flexing of soft power.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.S. Penalizes Libyan Politician in Effort to Bolster Unity Government
item.description: Libya’s new unity government, which was formed in December, has struggled to enforce its authority, which rival factions refuse to acknowledge.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Judge Rejects Challenge to Searches of Emails Gathered Without Warrant
item.description: The ruling is notable because some lawmakers want to require agencies to get a warrant before searching emails for an American’s name or email address.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: In Farewell, Fidel Castro Urges Party to Fulfill His Vision
item.media:description: Fidel Castro, left, with his brother, President Raúl Castro, addressed Cuba’s Communist Party at the party congress in Havana on Tuesday.
item.description: While Mr. Castro, 89, seemed to take his leave of the party on Tuesday, others in his cohort signaled their intentions to stay put.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Latvia Wants to Ban Face Veils, for All 3 Women Who Wear Them
item.media:description: Liga Legzdina, 27, who goes by the name Fatima, near Riga, Latvia. She is one of a tiny handful of women who wear the niqab in the country, and interactions on buses and trams, she said, often involve her being told to “go back to where you come from.”
item.media:credit: Reinis Hofmanis for The New York Times
item.description: A proposal to ban the veils, or niqabs, from public spaces is one expression of broader fears about immigration and Muslims in this small, homogeneous country.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Syria Cease-Fire Crumbles as Bombings Kill Dozens
item.media:description: The remains of a market in Maarat al-Noaman, in Syria’s northern province of Idlib, after an airstrike Tuesday. Dozens of people were reported killed.
item.description: Government warplanes attacked the towns of Maarat al-Noaman and Kafr Nabl a day after the main Syrian opposition group said it would no longer participate in talks in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: China Sentences Man to Death for Espionage, Saying He Sold Secrets
item.media:description: A poster warning against foreign spies in an alleyway in Beijing on Wednesday.
item.description: The penalty for a computer technician accused of leaking 150,000 classified documents highlights the government’s campaign against security threats.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Ukraine Leader Says Russia Appears to Agree to Prisoner Swap
item.media:description: Defendants Yevgeny Yerofeyev, left, and Aleksandr Aleksandrov sat in a cage during a trial session in Kiev, Ukraine, on April 15.
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko said that President Vladimir V. Putin “seemed” to approve of the deal that would bring home Lt. Nadiya V. Savchenko.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Germany Cracks Down on Far Right With Arrests and a Trial
item.description: A raid in Saxony led to the arrest of five people suspected of attacking refugee shelters, and the trial of an anti-immigrant group leader began.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Australian Premier, Malcolm Turnbull, Stymied by Senate, Calls for Election
item.description: The election, to be held July 2, will test Mr. Turnbull’s popularity with the public just seven months after taking office.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Palmyra Arch Replica Is Unveiled in Trafalgar Square in London
item.media:description: A scale replica of a landmark Roman arch that was destroyed by Islamic State fighters in Palmyra, Syria, was unveiled in Trafalgar Square, in London, on Tuesday.
item.description: The marble copy of the landmark, which was destroyed by Islamic State fighters, was built from digital models and will be displayed through Thursday.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte and Other Candidates Seeking to Lead Philippines Tap Into Aquino Fatigue
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte, second from left atop the vehicle, campaigning for president of the Philippines at Cainta Rizal, east of Manila, last week.
item.description: President Benigno S. Aquino III has overseen nearly six years of strong growth, but many voters say his administration has been indecisive and ineffective.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Memo From Brussels: A Close Look at Brussels Offers a More Nuanced View of Radicalization
item.media:description: Residents at a market in Molenbeek, a heavily immigrant neighborhood of Brussels, last month.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: A look at Molenbeek and other parts of Brussels suggests that immigrants from North Africa, particularly Morocco, are angrier and more alienated than the city’s Turks.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Israeli Convicted in Murder of Palestinian Teenager
item.media:description: The remains of Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, arriving in the Shuafat neighborhood of East Jerusalem before burial in July 2014.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: A judge rejected an insanity defense by Yosef Haim Ben-David, who could face a life sentence for the abduction and death of Muhammad Abu Khdeir.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere: Front-End Loaders in China Wage Heavy-Duty Combat Over Building Projects
item.description: Workers from one company had shown up at a concrete plant in a northern county intending to take over a new development project, the news media said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Taliban Send Message With Deadly Kabul Attack as Fighting Season Begins
item.description: A truck bomb that killed at least 30 people and wounded more than 300 underscored fears about the group’s ability to infiltrate the Afghan capital.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AHMAD SHAKIB

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Ning Zhu on the ‘Guaranteed Bubble’ in China’s Economy
item.media:description: Laborers at a construction site in Beijing.
item.description: Professor Zhu, a scholar at the Shanghai Advanced Institute of Finance, says government guarantees have encouraged hazardous levels of leverage as the economy slows.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: David Cameron’s Personal Finances
item.media:description: Protesters in Parliament Square, London, earlier this month.
item.description: With a referendum on Europe in the balance, it is not a good time for the prime minister to look like a rich toff.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Tackling Graft in India
item.description: An identity card program is helping to reduce corruption, but changing cultural norms is a huge task.
item.dc:creator: ANJA MANUEL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Obama Shouldn’t Trade Cluster Bombs for Saudi Arabia’s Friendship
item.media:description: President Obama with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, center, and Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, in May 2015.
item.description: Washington is trying to buy off Riyadh with weapons. The results are deadly.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM D. HARTUNG

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Dispatch from Dakar: ‘Where Is This Flight Going?’ and Other Basic Questions About African Travel
item.media:description: A moldy airplane on the runway in Cameroon.
item.description: In West Africa, getting there is way more than half the battle.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
